(a) Where the employment terminates for any reason other than misconduct or voluntary resignation and a superannuation allowance is not payable.
(b) Where a female officer or servant retires to get married, and
(c) Where an officer or servant is dismissed on account of grave misconduct. Reference has already been made to this class of case.

An officer or servant or the representatives of a deceased officer or servant aggrieved by the neglect or refusal of a mental hospital authority to make a grant may appeal to the Minister. Any existing officer or servant will have the right to signify within six months after the pension provisions of the Bill come into operation his intention not to avail himself of the provisions of the Bill, and in any such case the provisions of the Bill will not apply. Subject to this the Act of 1909 shall cease to operate.

Amongst the miscellaneous provisions of the Bill relating to mental hospital authorities is that provided for in Section 93 empowering the Minister to set up a joint authority to administer any particular service for two or more mental hospital districts where it appears to him after consultation with the mental hospital authorities concerned that joint management and administration would tend to reduce expense or would be otherwise of public or local advantage. Section 93 would enable the Minister to establish a joint authority to administer a joint auxiliary mental hospital.

Mental hospital authorities are given power to make arrangements for the maintenance of any class of chargeable patients in a special institution not maintained by them. Two mental hospital authorities may make and carry out an arrangement for the reception into the district mental hospital or any other institution, maintained by one such authority, of patients maintained by the other authority.

A very important provision made in Part IX of the Bill is that contained in Section 103 which empowers a mental hospital authority where a person is received as a chargeable patient into one of their institutions and is not ordinarily resident in their district to arrange for the transfer of the person to the district mental hospital for the mental hospital district in which he ordinarily resides. The section also imposes a liability on the mental hospital authority for the mental hospital district in which the person ordinarily resides to make payment in respect of the cost of the care, maintenance and treatment of the person in the mental institution to which he was first admitted.

It is well known that some persons when they become mentally unbalanced wander away from home and when they are apprehended as mental patients they may be far removed from the mental hospital district in which they ordinarily reside and there may be urgent reasons for having them immediately admitted to the district mental hospital for the district in which they are apprehended. Section 172, Part XIV, of the Bill provides for the admission of a person of unsound mind to the district mental hospital for the mental hospital district in which he is for the time being in a case of urgency or where the mental hospital district in which he ordinarily resides cannot readily be ascertained. It is very desirable that in any such case there should be power to send the mental patient back to a mental institution for the district in which he ordinarily resides.

The section is also intended to remedy a situation which has long been a matter of much concern to mental hospital authorities in large centres of population, particularly to the joint committee of management of Grangegorman Mental Hospital. Numbers of patients are admitted to Grangegorman Mental Hospital who do not ordinarily reside in the mental hospital district. Many of these patients may be persons who have genuinely come to Dublin in search of employment and have become mentally ill after a short period, but it is understood that some of the patients are brought to Dublin for the express purpose of having them received into a mental hospital far removed from their native place in order to conceal from their friends and acquaintances the fact that they have found it necessary to seek mental treatment. It is undoubtedly unjust that the rate-payers of Grangegorman Mental Hospital district should be required to bear the cost of the care, maintenance and treatment of these classes of persons, and I think that the position calls for remedial measures.

Other sections in this part of the Bill to which I would draw attention are Section 102, which enables a mental hospital authority to provide for the burial of the remains of a person who dies while in receipt of mental hospital assistance from them, and Section 104, which empowers a mental hospital authority to provide by regulations for the admission of paying patients to any institution maintained by them.

Part X of the Bill provides for the registration of private institutions by the Minister. A private institution means an institution or premises in which one or more than one person of unsound mind is or are taken care of and in respect of whom the whole of the cost of maintenance and treatment is paid,

As already stated, such institutions were required to be licensed annually by the Circuit Courts in pursuance of the Act of 1842. The Commission on the Relief of the Sick and Destitute Poor, in their report of 1927, recommended that the power to license these institutions should be transferred from the Circuit Courts to the Minister. The Minister's functions of administration in relation to the care and treatment of mental patients furnish a good reason for the transfer. He is in close touch with those institutions and he is kept informed of the conditions obtaining in them by the inspector of mental hospitals who inspects them periodically.

Part X of the Bill sets out in detail the procedure for the registration of the institutions by the Minister, and the grounds upon which registration or renewal of registration may be refused and the grounds upon which an institution may be removed from the register. An institution remains registered for a period of 12 months, but there is provision for renewal of registration. The Minister is empowered to make regulations for the administration of private institutions and for medical attendance on patients therein and to prescribe the medical staffs to be employed and the records to be kept.

Part XI of the Bill makes provision for the registration of private charitable institutions by the Minister. A private charitable institution is an institution carried on wholly or mainly for the care of persons of unsound mind gratuitously or at less than cost. The proposal to register these institutions is made in accordance with a recommendation by the commission which reported in 1927. The provisions relating to the registration of private charitable institutions are much the same as those proposed for private institutions—the differences are that there will be no power to require private charitable institutions to pay any fees in respect of registration, and these institutions will be required to furnish the Minister annually with an abstract of their accounts. The latter requirement is intended to enable the Minister to satisfy himself that the institutions come within the definition of private charitable institution given in the Bill.

In the case of an institution authorised by special Act or other enactment, including a charter, for the care, maintenance and treatment of persons of unsound mind Part XII of the Bill will give power to the Minister to take steps to satisfy himself as to the competency of the person in charge, the arrangements for the medical attendance of patients, the suitability and adequacy of the food given to the patients, and the accommodation in and state of repair of each institution. Where the Minister is not satisfied on any of these matters he may order the person carrying on the institution to take such steps as he considers proper. Where there has been a conviction for a contravention of any such order the Minister may direct that the care of mental patients in the institution shall be discontinued.

Part XIII of the Bill gives the Minister power to approve of institutions for the reception of temporary patients and voluntary patients. These two classes of patients are dealt with later in the Bill. The Minister may approve of an institution for the reception of one or other or of both classes. The reception of temporary and voluntary patients in an institution not approved by the Minister is prohibited. The Minister is empowered to make regulations governing the administration of approved institutions and prescribing the staffs to be employed and the records to be kept in relation to the temporary patients and the voluntary patients received for treatment.

The reception of persons of unsound mind into mental institutions is dealt with in Part XIV of the Bill and this part will require an extensive explanation for the reason that it makes a radical alteration in the existing law and procedure. Hitherto persons suffering from derangement of mind could be admitted into mental institutions under the control of mental hospital authorities in various ways. The usual methods of admission were:—

(1) Committal in pursuance of Section 10 of the Lunacy (Ireland) Act, 1867. The committal order was made by two peace commissioners or a district justice after the person concerned had been certified as a dangerous lunatic by a dispensary medical officer. The expenses connected with the committal, including the payment to the medical officer for his services, were defrayed by the local public assistance authority.

(2) Admission in pursuance of regulations adopted by the mental hospital authority. These regulations contained provision for admission on a prescribed form in which was included a certificate to be signed by one medical practitioner and an order of admission to be made by one peace commissioner. All the costs connected with the certification were borne by the next of kin or the person seeking the patient's admission.

(3) Admission as a paying patient in pursuance of regulations adopted by the mental hospital authority. The regulations prescribed a form of certificate to be signed by two medical practitioners and an order of admission to be signed by one peace commissioner. All the costs and expenses connected with certification were borne by the next of kin.

In addition to these modes of admission there were others which have not much bearing on the consideration of this Bill inasmuch as they relate to a comparatively small number of admissions and it is not proposed to make any change in regard to them. They are: Admission on the order of the President of the High Court in the case of a ward of court; admission of members of the Defence Forces certified on discharge or retirement to be of unsound mind; admission on the order of the Minister for Justice in the case of a prisoner.

In case of mental institutions which are not under the control of mental hospital authorities admission can be obtained in two ways, namely: (1) A patient can be admitted to an institution licensed in pursuance of the Act of 1842 on the order of a relative or other person accompanied by two certificates, each signed by a medical practitioner to the effect that the patient has been examined by him, and that he is of unsound mind and is a proper person to be confined; (2) a patient can be admitted to other private mental institutions on a certificate signed by two medical practitioners accompanied by an order of admission signed by one peace commissioner.

The great majority of poor persons are admitted to district mental hospitals following committal under Section 10 of the Act of 1867. Admission under regulations by the second method mentioned in relation to institutions maintained by mental hospital authorities is largely confined to persons transferred from county homes to district mental hospitals.

Section 10 of the Act of 1867 was based on principles embodied in previous legislation under which a person suffering from mental illness was committed to an institution as if he were guilty of some crime. The Act of 1838, to which I have already made reference, provided that if any person were discovered and apprehended under circumstances denoting derangement of mind and a purpose of committing some crime which, if committed, would render him liable to be indicated, any two justices before whom the person was brought could call to their assistance any legally qualified physician, surgeon or apothecary, and if upon examination of the person or from any other proof, the justices were satisfied that he was a dangerous lunatic or a dangerous idiot, they could commit him to gaol to be kept therein until discharged. Where it was certified by two physicians or surgeons, or a physician and a surgeon, that any such person was insane, the Lord Lieutenant could, if he thought fit, direct by warrant the removal of the person from the gaol to the lunatic asylum established for the county, city or town in which he was in custody.

Although the Act of 1867 prohibited the committal of lunatics to gaols, it will be seen from what I have already said that Section 10 of that Act retained the objectionable features of the earlier Act. It even repeated the language as to the person being apprehended under circumstances denoting derangement of mind and a purpose of committing an indictable crime.

The procedure under the Act of 1867 is that the Gárda apprehend the person and bring him before two peace commissioners before whom evidence is given that the person is dangerous and likely to commit an indictable crime, When it is proved to the satisfaction of the peace commissioners that the person was discovered and apprehended under circumstances denoting derangement of mind and a purpose of committing an indictable offence the peace commissioners call to their assistance the dispensary medical officer and if he certifies that the person is a dangerous lunatic or a dangerous idiot the peace commissioners, by warrant, direct the person to be taken to the district mental hospital for the district in which he was apprehended. This procedure has much in common with that followed in a criminal case. The patient is dealt with as if he were suspected of being guilty of a crime.

The Bill proposes to depart entirely from this procedure and to deal with persons suffering from mental derangement as patients who are mentally ill and who should be arranged for and treated by medical practitioners.
Broadly speaking two methods for the admission of persons of unsound mind to mental institutions are provided for—one relating to chargeable patients and the other to private patients.

The Bill provides that where it is desired to have a person admitted to a district mental hospital as a person of unsound mind and a chargeable patient, application may be made to the authorised medical officer for a recommendation for the reception and detention of the person in such mental hospital. The application may be made by the husband, or wife or a relative of the person concerned, or, at the request of any of them, by the appropriate assistance officer, or by any other person. The authorised medical officer is the medical officer of the dispensary district in which the person ordinarily resides, if he is not disqualified in relation to the person, and if he is so disqualified, then the dispensary medical officer residing nearest to the place where the person ordinarily resides who is available and is not disqualified. Where there are more medical officers than one in a dispensary district the nearest available of those officers who is not disqualified in relation to the person is the authorised medical officer. If none of these medical officers is available or all of them disqualified or some not available and the remainder disqualified then the nearest available dispensary medical officer who is not disqualified is the authorised medical officer. A medical officer is disqualified in relation to a person if he is interested in the payments to be made for taking care of the person or if he is a family connection of the person.

The medical officer to whom the application is made is required to visit and examine the person within 24 hours of the receipt of the application, and if he is satisfied that it is proper to do so he shall make the recommendation. The applicant for the recommendation or any person authorised by him may then convey the person to the district mental hospital. On arrival of the person at the mental hospital the resident medical superintendent, or another medical officer of the hospital acting on his behalf, is required to examine the person and, if he is satisfied that he is of unsound mind, to make an order for his reception and detention as a person of unsound mind in the mental hospital.

The expenses of the conveyance of the person to the mental hospital may be paid by the assistance officer. There is also provision enabling the resident medical superintendent of the mental hospital and requiring the Gárda Síochána, to provide an escort if one is required to ensure the safe conveyance of the person to the mental hospital.

Provision is also made to enable the Gárda Síochána to take steps to have a person admitted to the district mental hospital where he is of unsound mind, and should for the public safety or the safety of himself be placed under care and control and also to have a person of unsound mind admitted where he is not under proper care or control or is neglected or cruelly treated.

Where it is desired to have a person received and detained as a person of unsound mind in an authorised institution or a private institution or a private charitable institution, or as a paying patient in a district mental hospital, application may be made to a registered medical practitioner for a private patient reception order. The application may be made by the husband or wife or a relative of the person, or by any other person. If the registered medical practitioner accepts the application he is required to arrange with another practitioner for two separate examinations of the person, one examination by each practitioner, and if they are each separately satisfied that it is proper to do so they shall make an order for the reception of the person in a mental institution. The applicant for the order, or any person authorised by him, may then convey the person to the mental institution mentioned in the order. The person may then be received and detained in such institution. The Gárda Síochána are required in this case also to arrange for an escort, if one is required, to ensure the safe conveyance of the person to the institution.

Part XIV of the Bill also provides for the reception of temporary patients in mental institutions. For the purposes of the Bill a temporary patient is defined as a person who is suffering from mental illness and who is believed to require for his recovery not more than three months suitable mental hospital treatment and is unfit on account of his mental state for treatment as a voluntary patient.

In this connection I should mention that since fixing the period of three months, set out in the Bill as the limiting period for the detention of temporary patients, representations have been made to me, mostly by medical experts who are concerned in the treatment of these patients, that the period of three months is altogether too short. We can deal with that in Committee. We could extend the period and make it six months, I understand that up to 60 per cent. of such cases admitted to mental hospitals are in fact discharged within a six months period. If when I check up on the representations that have been made I find that they are accurate I think it would be a very sound policy to extend the period of detention of temporary patients to six months.

A large number of the patients admitted to mental institutions suffer from mental illness which is of comparatively short duration. Statistics contained in the report of the Commission on the Relief of the Sick and Destitute Poor show that of those discharged from district mental hospitals and auxiliary mental hospitals 30.9 per cent. were discharged within a period of three months of their admission. Many of those patients are never again admitted to a mental institution. They had evidently suffered from a mental illness which responded to treatment after a very short period of care. It is undesirable that in order to obtain treatment such persons must be formally certified as of unsound mind and admitted to a mental institution where they are placed in the same category as persons suffering from prolonged or permanent forms of mental disease.

The Bill proposes to make provision for the admission of temporary patients to institutions approved by the Minister for the reception of such patients. In this connection I might say that approved institutions need not necessarily be mental institutions, although probably a number of them will be mental institutions. It is quite possible that the illness from which the patients suffer may be of a nature that could be treated in a general hospital with special facilities for the treatment of such cases. Sometimes the nervous or mental disorder is directly or indirectly caused or aggravated by disease requiring special medical or surgical treatment. These are aspects of the matter to be examined by the Minister, and if he is satisfied that suitable arrangements are available in a general hospital for the treatment of the diseases from which temporary patients suffer, it will be open to him to give approval to the hospital for the purposes of the admission of temporary patients thereto so as to enable such patients to benefit by the facilities afforded in the hospital.

The Bill provides that where it is desired to have a person received and detained as a temporary patient in an approved institution application on that behalf may be made to the person in charge of the institution. The application may be made by the husband or wife or a relative of the patient, or by any other person, and in the case of a chargeable patient application may also be made by the appropriate assistance officer at the request of the husband or wife or a relative. The apaplication must be accompanied by a medical certificate, which in the case of a chargeable patient must be given by the authorised medical officer. After consideration of the application the person in charge of the institution may, if he thinks it proper to do so, make a temporary patient reception order to have the person received and detained as a temporary patient in the institution.

The applicant for the order or any person authorised by him may then convey the person to whom the order relates to the institution, where he may be detained for a period not exceeding three months. If the person is a chargeable patient the appropriate assistance officer may defray the reasonable expenses of his conveyance to the institution, and if the institution to which the person is to be removed is a district mental hospital the mental hospital authority may cooperate in making arrangements for the removal.

Part XV of the Bill proposes to make provision for the reception of voluntary patients in institutions approved by the Minister for the purpose. A voluntary patient is a person who, being 16 years of age or over, submits himself voluntarily for treatment for illness of a mental or kindred nature, or who, if he is less than 16 years of age, is submitted voluntarily by a parent or guardian.

It is the considered opinion of specialists engaged in the treatment of mental disease that to reduce the numbers in the mental institutions attention should be focussed on the treatment of early cases of mental disorder and that failure to make provision for the treatment of such cases must result in an increase of the numbers suffering from mental afflictions and requiring prolonged or permanent treatment in mental institutions.

The arguments already put forward in favour of the establishment of consulting rooms and clinics apply with equal force to the provision of facilities for the treatment of voluntary patients. Persons suspecting symptoms of mental or nervous disease should be encouraged to seek advice and treatment in the early stages before the disease is too far developed. It is essential, therefore, to remove all formalities such as certification and formal committal to mental institutions which are likely to deter or discourage patients from seeking treatment of their own accord. The Commission on the Relief of the Sick and Destitute Poor held similar views, as they wrote in their report:—

“By establishing a system of voluntary admissions persons in the early stages of mental disease would be encouraged to seek treatment at a time when it can be given with the greatest advantage. There can be no doubt that the objection to certification and to the idea of detention leads to postponement of skilled advice and treatment until the patient becomes obviously certifiable. The presence of voluntary patients would, we think, help in developing the curative function of the mental hospitals and in bringing about a healthier public attitude towards these institutions.”
In the case of voluntary patients also the institutions approved by the Minister for reception of the patients may be general hospitals or mental institutions.

When an institution is being examined for the purposes of approval for the reception of voluntary patients the qualifications of the staff and the facilities proposed for the care and treatment of patients and the general suitability of the institution will be matters for consideration.

The Bill provides that when it is desired to have a person received into an institution as a voluntary patient application may be made to the person in charge of the institution by the parent or guardian, if the person is under 16 years of age, and in any other case by the person himself. The application must be accompanied by a medical recommendation which, in the case of a chargeable patient, must be furnished by the authorised medical officer.

When the application is made the person may be received into the approved institution and treated therein as a voluntary patient. The assistance officer may pay the reasonable expenses of conveyance to the institution in the case of a chargeable patient. Seventy-two hours' notice is required of the proposed departure from the institution of a voluntary patient not less than 16 years of age. Where a voluntary patient is less than 16 years of age the parent or guardian is entitled to remove the patient at any time after he gives notice of his wish to do so.

Special provisions in relation to persons received and detained in mental institutions in pursuance of reception orders are contained in Part XVI of the Bill. There is power to allow any such person to be absent on trial for specified periods and power to send a person of unsound mind to another institution for the benefit of his health or for treatment. One of the sections in Part XVI of the Bill to which I would like to draw special attention is Section 201 which empowers mental hospital authorities to board out in private dwellings persons detained as chargeable patients in district mental hospitals or other institutions maintained by them. This is the first time that statutory authority has been given for such boarding-out in this country.

Power to board-out in private houses has been availed of in Scotland for the past 80 or 90 years. In that country the proportion of boarded-out persons to the total is sometimes as high as one to five. In some areas the proportion has gone up to 39 per cent. Boarding-out is stated to be extensive in Norway where there are practically as many patients boarded-out as there are in mental institutions. In Norway the cost of maintaining persons boarded-out varies from 50 per cent. to 75 per cent. of the cost of maintaining them in institutions.
The Commission on the Relief of the Sick and Destitute Poor wrote on this subject in their report:

“The Lunacy Acts contain no provisions authorising the boarding out of the insane, and, therefore, no experiment in this direction has heretofore been possible. Whether a system of boarding-out could be successfully established is a question on which opinion is divided. Success would largely depend on the manner in which it would be worked, on the kind of guardians who could be got to receive patients, and on the attitude of the community. Where the local authority are prepared to try boarding-out, we think it should be permitted under the safeguards as to inspection which have been found necessary in other countries. It would be prudent in the beginning to board-out patients only in the neighbourhood of the mental hospitals where they could be visited at intervals by the medical officers and also seen by the inspector on his visits, a mode of boarding-out followed in some continental countries.”

It is not possible to anticipate how far the system of boarding-out would be availed of in this country. At least one mental hospital authority has asked for legislation to permit of boarding-out. There should be a large number of patients in mental institutions who would be suitable for boarding-out and who would be much happier living in a private dwelling where they could enjoy the freedom and home associations not usually available to them when confined in a large institution controlled by stringent regulations.

Under Section 201 of the Bill boarding-out would be confined to persons who are not dangerous to themselves or others and who do not require treatment in an institution. The section makes detailed provision for the care, inspection and supervision of boarded-out persons.

Part XVI of the Bill also sets out the procedure for the discharge of patients from mental institutions. In this matter I would like to draw attention to Section 212, which empowers a mental hospital authority to direct any of their medical officers to visit, after his discharge from one of their institutions, any person for the purpose of giving him advice as to any mental treatment which he should undergo.

In regard to the recovery of the cost of maintenance and treatment in institutions maintained by mental hospital authorities the provisions of the Bill are similar to those in the Public Assistance Act, 1939. There is, however, in Section 222 a special power enabling a District Court to appoint a person to represent a patient for all purposes connected with proceedings to recover payment.
The powers and duties of the Inspector of Mental Hospitals as defined in Part XVIII of the Bill are similar to those already devolving on him.

There is little that calls for explanation in the concluding part of the Bill. This part deals largely with legal proceedings and penalties. The provisions as regards inquiries ordered by the Minister are set out precisely and in more detail than in existing enactments.

Section 262 relates to members of the Defence Forces who on retirement, relinquishment of commission, or discharge are certified to be of unsound mind. The section is a proposed reenactment of Section 2 of the Defence Forces (Temporary Provisions) Act, 1925, as amended by Section 8 of the Defence Forces (Temporary Provisions) Act, 1942. It is considered that this Bill is the appropriate one to provide for the matter dealt with in those sections.

The Bill does not deal with the law relating to criminal lunatics. Neither does it affect the law administered by the courts in connection with lunatics and their property. Section 272 expressly provides that the Bill shall not affect the powers exercised by the President of the High Court or a judge of the Circuit Court in this matter.

The Bill does not propose to deal with mental deficiency or mentally deficient persons, that is, persons who do not possess their full mental faculties and whose mental deficiency cannot be cured. This class differs entirely from persons of unsound mind who at some time possessed their full mental faculties but who through mental disease or illness have become mentally disordered. Such persons may recover after a period of treatment, either long or short, or their mental faculties may be permanently deranged.

The Bill before the House deals in a comprehensive way with the whole question of mental treatment. It represents the results of some years of study during which I have, in consultation with the officers of my Department, personally examined every conceivable aspect of the problems presented by mental disease. I confess to the feeling that the time and energy devoted to the work has been well worth while, and I hope the Bill that will emerge following our detailed discussions will embody a statutory code that will be well in advance of the corresponding provisions in the countries where legislation dealing with mental treatment is abreast of modern scientific thought.

Speaker.P: The Parliamentary Secretary is to be congratulated on his interesting historical survey of the methods adopted for the treatment of mental patients in the past. He indicated quite clearly that the treatment was very casual, due, presumably to the fact that the number of people suffering from mental disorders in those days was not nearly so numerous as it is to-day. In any event, we have made tremendous strides and advances since then, and the Bill which the Parliamentary Secretary has introduced proposes, as I understand his statement, to deal in a comprehensive way with the whole problem of mental disease in this country. It is designed to codify all the existing laws and regulations with regard to the treatment of mentally deficient people, and I must say it would be a feat almost beyond the ability of any member of the House to study and master the 272 sections of this huge Bill in the short period at their disposal. However, the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill enables Deputies to master its general details sufficiently, at all events, to discuss the measure intelligently and to make whatever useful suggestions they may consider necessary for the purpose of improving the Bill.

MainHeading.P: The Parliamentary Secretary stressed one point, that is, the importance of mentally defective people receiving early treatment. One of the troubles in the past and, I think, one of the things responsible to a large extent for the spread of mental disease in this country, is the fact that people suffering from the worst forms of the disease never received treatment in time. They were allowed to go on suffering for an indefinite period without any kind of medical or specialised treatment, and the result, I assume, was that the longer they suffered, the more chronic the disease became. When finally, because they had become nuisances to the families with which they resided, they were removed to institutions, the disease was so advanced that treatment there was very often not at all effective. But that is generally true of every part of the country, I think.

Whether the fact that in future patients have to be certified by doctors rather than by peace commissioners will have the effect of getting earlier treatment for such patients, I do not know, but I think that in a measure of this kind the Parliamentary Secretary should take steps to see that medical officers are notified as early as possible of the people who are suffering from mental disease, and especially serious types or serious forms of mental disease. It is only in that way that we shall succeed in counteracting the spread of the disease and in minimising the dangers resulting from contacts between people suffering from the disease and the general body of the people.

I personally welcome the change that in future the certificate has to be issued by a medical officer in place of the committal notice by a peace commissioner. I was personally always of the opinion that any patient should be certified by a medical officer before being admitted to a mental institution. These patients who were committed by peace commissioners were probably examined some long time afterwards by the resident medical superintendents or the assistant resident medical superintendents of these institutions, but the examination in some cases was perhaps rather casual. It was not as specialised or as careful as it should be, and sometimes it has happened that people have been detained in these institutions when, as a matter of fact, they should have been sent to rather another type of institution. But, in any event, as I said a moment ago, even with a doctor's certificate, unless steps are taken by the Parliamentary Secretary to ensure that all people suffering from the more extreme forms of mental disorder are notified to the public health authorities early on, there is a danger that even the certification by the medical officer will not have the effect which the Parliamentary Secretary intends.

Another point I wish to make is that, from my experience of mental institutions, I think it is a mistake, and I always thought it was a mistake, that all the patients, irrespective of the degree of their mental disorder, were herded together in one big institutional building. I am merely expressing a layman's opinion, but I think that the patients should be segregated, that the worse type of patients should be kept in one part of the institution, that the people not so seriously affected should be kept in another portion of it, and that the other patients, who are probably only suffering from a relatively mild form of mental disorder, should be kept in still another portion of it. I know from my experience that in the past, at all events, these patients, irrespective of the degree of the disease from which they were suffering, were all herded together. I suggest, therefore, to the Parliamentary Secretary that, in the course of time, when perhaps money is more plentiful, now that the Minister is planning all sorts of wonderful social service schemes for the future, the surroundings of these mental hospitals could be made more appropriate and that better buildings could be substituted for some of our existing mental hospitals. They possess too much of the appearance of a military barracks. I think that the very appearance or the very atmosphere of them is not at all conducive to the improvement or the cure of the patients immured within their walls. I have been told by doctors and others who have treated mental patients that the surroundings of the patients have a very important bearing on their cure, and I suggest that the appearance of some of these institutions in which they are immured at present would not be calculated to lead to any marked improvement in the condition of some of the patients in them.

It is an admirable suggestion, I think, that harmless patients should be boarded out with private persons. The home atmosphere, the home environment, and the domestic surroundings will be conducive probably to restoring a normal condition of mind in these people, certainly much more rapidly than if they were kept in any sort of institution. I think that is certainly an admirable move, and I compliment the Parliamentary Secretary on that, at all events. I also think that it is a wise move to remove the word “lunatic” from our legislation. There is a sort of stigma attaching to the name. It has an unpleasant flavour and it reminds us of things that probably most of us would like to forget.

Another important proposal in the Bill is the establishment, with the consent of the Minister, in suitable centres, of clinics and consulting rooms for the treatment of people suffering from all kinds of nervous disorders. Again I speak as a layman, but I think that the number of people in this country suffering from nervous disorders is very large indeed. It may be due to the strain of the lives they are leading or to the terrible times through which we are passing, but nervous disorders of one kind or another are undoubtedly very common. The unfortunate part of it is that most of the people suffering from nervous disorders are not in a financial position to obtain suitable treatment under present conditions. Of course, people who are suffering from a nervous breakdown or other types of nervous disorders who are in a good financial position can afford to come to Dublin and consult eminent specialists and receive treatment suitable to these diseases. But the overwhelming majority of the people who are suffering from these nervous disorders are not in a position to come as far as Dublin and they are not in a position to get suitable treatment in the centres in which they reside. I, therefore, welcome that provision in the Bill under which the Minister is taking power to provide clinics and consulting rooms for the treatment of people suffering from these kinds of nervous disorders. It is a wise provision and it shows clearly that the Minister is cognisant of conditions in the country and that it is necessary to make provision for them.

Provision is also made for the registering of private mental hospitals. Most of us in our young days, I suppose, read a famous book dealing with private mental hospitals written by a man whose books were a great vogue in our young days, that is, in the young days of the Minister and myself; the Parliamentary Secretary is not quite so old as either of us. However, we are inclined perhaps to have an unjustified suspicion in our minds about private mental hospitals. I know they are conducted in an admirable way, and I am sure that the Parliamentary Secretary or the Minister has seen to it that these institutions are conducted in accordance with the regulations and that the patients in them receive every care and attention, in so far as existing regulations allow the Minister to look after them.

In any event, I think that, when we are dealing with such a terrible disease as this, the Minister should take drastic powers to see that the institutions in which these unfortunate people are confined should come under Government control. I assume that the registration which is proposed in this Bill will give much wider and more drastic powers than the existing licensing regulations. I assume that licensing simply meant that the owner of the institution had to apply to the court and obtain the necessary licence and that the degree of control exercised by the Minister was somewhat limited. I assume that, under the legislation proposed in this Bill, private mental hospitals will be dealt with almost in the same way as the mental hospitals maintained out of the rates.

Another proposal is that in certain counties the mental hospitals will be controlled by joint boards. The name sounds important, but I am wondering if the joint boards proposed in the Bill will have any more control than the former committees of management or the existing visiting committees. After all, under the Managerial Act committees in charge of mental hospitals have been practically divested of all power and authority, except that they have power admittedly to make proposals to their county councils for the purpose of the striking of a rate for the maintenance of the mental hospitals in which they are interested. But it seems to me that it is not worth while constituting a joint board under the Bill unless the Minister gives them some real degree of authority. I assume that they will have the same authority as the existing committees, that is to say, authority to make proposals to the county council for the striking of a rate sufficient to maintain the institution, that they can go round the building and have a look at the patients and report back to the county manager their views about the treatment of the patients, the food they receive, and so on. After all, this Bill is revolutionary in many ways, and it does appear to me that, if these joint boards are to be effective, they will have to be given a much wider range of authority than that enjoyed by the present visiting committees.

Now, there have been discussions at meetings of public boards recently about the capitation grant. There is not a word about the capitation grant in this Bill. I do not know whether it is the Minister's or the Parliamentary Secretary's intention to deal with this matter in another Bill, but at all events the cost of maintaining patients in public institutions is a very important item at the present moment. I do not know whether the Parliamentary Secretary is aware that the present capitation grant amounts to only £10 per patient, whereas the actual cost of maintaining the patient in a mental institution is between £75 and £80. The disparity is very great. Almost all local authorities have been agitating in order to get the grant increased. I thought the Parliamentary Secretary would deal with that aspect in this Bill. I think he will admit—I am not so sure that he has not already admitted it to a deputation—that the present basis of the capitation grant is entirely inadequate to meet modern demands and that it needs to be revised. If the Minister cannot see his way to revise the basis of the grant in this Bill, I hope he will do so in a later measure.

The Minister is giving mental hospital committees very wide powers to acquire land. I am not very clear as to what powers the sections in the Land Clauses Acts give. Do they give local authorities the right to acquire land for development purposes as well as building purposes?

Speaker.P: For the purposes of their functions—the powers are fairly wide.

I assume that, according to the section in the Bill, the mental hospital committees will have the right and the power to buy land for farming and tillage purposes. I do not mind giving the local authorities power to acquire land for building purposes and for the purposes of reasonable development in the way of providing gardens for growing vegetables, but I do object to giving mental hospital committees power to acquire land compulsorily for the purpose of farming operations of any kind. I believe, in equity and justice, mental hospital committees, if they want land for farming purposes, should go into the open market and purchase at the current market prices.
They might not be able to get it in the right geographical position. If it is too far away it might not be of much use to them.
Will the compulsory powers help them in that direction?
Oh, yes.

We will assume all these mental institutions already have the lands adjoining. We know that most of them have a substantial acreage, so it is not vitally important that land should be acquired in the immediate neighbourhood of the mental hospital. Surely, they can go some distance away and buy land at current market prices. It is grossly unfair that any public authority should take powers of this sort and deprive farmers of land which they may urgently require for the purpose of creating a livelihood for themselves and their families. I suggest it is taking an unfair advantage of a Parliamentary institution such as the Dáil to request it to give the Minister authority of that kind.

MainHeading.P: My impression is that in the past mental hospital committees went into the open market and bought land at the prevailing market price. So far as I am aware, I do not think there was a complaint from any mental hospital committee that it could not find all the land it wanted convenient to the institution. I am perfectly certain that without these compulsory powers the mental hospital committees will be able to buy all the land they want, for the purpose of extending their farming operations, convenient to the institution.

The Bill is largely a machinery Bill. It is a measure that could more properly be discussed by medical experts, because it deals in the main with medical matters. There are not many aspects of the Bill that lend themselves to a Second Reading debate. Generally speaking, the Bill seems to be designed to facilitate people suffering from mental diseases and to enable them to receive treatment in a convenient, unobtrusive and inexpensive way. The intention is admirable, and I hope that when the Bill becomes law, with suitable amendments, it will achieve the aim that the Parliamentary Secretary has in mind and that it will bring a much-needed measure of relief to the unfortunate people who suffer from this dread disease.

Speaker.P: As Deputy Roddy has pointed out, we welcome this Bill as a non-contentious measure and as a step in the right direction. It aims at codifying the law with regard to the treatment offered to mental cases. It is the first measure of its kind in so far as the codification of existing laws goes. I am sure that from the legal aspect it will be welcomed. It simplifies the whole position because it places in one Act all the existing legislation relating to the treatment of mental diseases. But it goes beyond that and it modernises and simplifies the entry of patients into institutions.

MainHeading.P: The Parliamentary Secretary has stressed one important point, and that is the necessity for early treatment of this disease. I suppose that as a medical man he appreciates that much more than we do. But we, too, appreciate it because we realise that it is largely due to the stigma attaching to the disease that there is a desire on the part of people to hide it until such time as it is too late to bring about effective treatment. Unfortunately, the tendency is to hide the fact that the disease is there, and it is extremely difficult for a patient to respond to treatment when the disease is not caught in its incipient stage. The very formal methods that were practised in order to commit a patient to a mental hospital did not commend themselves to the relatives of mentally diseased people. There was a good deal of publicity over the entry of a patient into a mental home. It soon became known to the neighbours, and the diseased man or woman was branded as a lunatic.

The removal of the term “lunatic” is, to my mind, a very advisable thing, as also is the removal of formal committal by a peace commissioner. The various facilities provided in the Bill for short courses of treatment without certification are admirable in themselves and in no way contentious. The Parliamentary Secretary has stated the short period of treatment as being three months, though it may be necessary to revise that provision. I think it should be made a bit longer.

There is one point which strikes me in regard to certification and I am sure the Parliamentary Secretary has adverted to it also. A medical practitioner who certifies a doubtful patient may leave himself open to litigation afterwards, and I wonder if the necessity to protect the practitioner has been considered. It is true that, if he were immune from any legal proceedings, there might be abuse, as a medical practitioner might, for a base motive, commit a neighbour of his who was not mentally diseased at all. I know two or three cases where there was some difficulty about certifying individuals, on account of the caution of certain practitioners. That point should be examined, but there is no reference to it in the Bill.

Many resolutions were passed in recent years in regard to capitation grants. Originally it was intended that the grant would cover 50 per cent. of the cost of treatment. While this Bill specifically provides for the financial obligations of the local authority, no reference whatever is made to the obligations of the central authority. Mental hospitals are becoming more and more a State service and I disagree with Deputy Roddy in regard to the responsibility put on mental hospital committees. We all know that those committees are merely ornamental at present. There is provision here for a seal, to make them more ornamental still; but I do not know what they have to seal. The responsibility for these hospitals is being vested to a large extent in the county manager, which proves my contention that these hospitals are becoming more and more a State service. It is very unfair that the local authority should have to bear the cost, as the charge then falls on the local ratepayers, who are largely the local farmers. Why should the man who has to work hard on the land have to provide the major portion of the cost of this treatment, while those enjoying big salaries and living in houses with a nominal valuation get off almost scot free? I would go so far as to say that the treatment of mental disorders in this country should be 100 per cent. a State responsibility, without any local charge at all.

There is provision in the Bill for pathological examination and research work and that is a step in the right direction which no Deputy would dare criticise. This is a very grave and unfortunate disease, when it attacks a family, and it is more unfortunate still that it is hereditary. We would all very much like to see proper research carried out, to ensure that the very latest methods of treatment are operated here. That involves more expense, but there is no attempt in the Bill to provide any increased financial assistance from the State and the whole financial responsibility is thrown back on the local ratepayers, making it finally a charge on agriculture to a very great extent. That is a major defect in the Bill. Our difficulty in discussing this matter in Committee will be that, if we attempt to put down amendments regarding the financial aspect, they will be ruled out of order as involving an increased charge on the State. Therefore, I can only appeal to the Parliamentary Secretary to reconsider the matter and come to the assistance of the ratepayers by making the State responsible.

I can compliment the Parliamentary Secretary on the great advance he is attempting to achieve in this Bill, by provision for the treatment of this disease in its various stages. This Bill is an attempt to deal with the incipient stage and to try to save individuals and families from being branded definitely as suffering from lunacy, where the mental disorder may be merely of a temporary nature. This segregation, however, will increase the cost and, while the provision is a desirable one, it is hardly fair to put all the increased cost on the major industry in the country.

Experimentation in boarding out patients is very desirable, to provide them with the environment of home life and get them interested in general matters, away from any mental trouble; and this policy may be a cure in itself. Regarding the acquisition of land, it would be most unfair to certain individuals in the vicinity of such institutions that the local authority should have absolute power to acquire land. I have no doubt that it may be desirable and necessary to have farms for therapeutic treatment, so that people suffering from mental diseases may be out in the open, working on the land and taking an interest in that work. Compulsory acquisition ought not to be resorted to except in very special cases.

From my experience, I do not know of any case where a mental hospital committee found any great difficulty in purchasing land in the open market. Even if a farm is a little bit away from a mental hospital there should be no difficulty in transporting the patients to it. In the case of a number of other institutions their farms are often situate some distance from them. In my opinion, the procedure envisaged here by the Parliamentary Secretary might be very bitterly resented.

I know, for example, that in the case of an institution which serves the counties of Carlow and Kildare a number of small economic holdings are in the vicinity of it. I think that if any attempt were made to compulsorily acquire one of them, unless, in addition to paying compensation to the owner, you were to provide him with an alternative farm, you would be doing that man and his family a great injustice. I think it would be going a bit too far. In saying that, I am not arguing against the wisdom, from the medical point of view, of providing additional land and facilities for the treatment of patients in mental hospitals: for removing them, so to speak, from their prison life and getting them out on the land. I can see all the advantages that employment on the land would have for them. I am, however, looking at it from an outsider's point of view and not from that of the medical man.

The proposal in the Bill that the membership of a mental hospital management committee should consist wholly of members of the local authority is a departure from the present practice, and I question the wisdom of it. You have, in almost every county, individuals who, while not members of the local authority, take a very keen interest in the treatment of mental cases and in the administration of county mental hospitals. I think that to deprive these institutions of the services of such people would be a retrograde step.

The superannuation provisions in the Bill are much wider than any that have been introduced hitherto. The provision for widows and dependent children is an admirable one. The only objection that I have to these sections is this, that the Parliamentary Secretary, instead of making provision for children up to the age of 16 years, might have fixed the age at 18 years. A child at the age of 16 is not yet fit to accept responsibility and take its part in the battle of life. I think that the Parliamentary Secretary might very well extend the age to 18 years. Possibly, he may say that the State should have no further responsibility once the child reaches 16 years: that it should then be fit to earn its own livelihood. Well, since the State going so far as to provide for children up to the age of 16 it might very well, I think, go a little bit further and extend the age to 18 years.

The provision with regard to the payment of a lump sum will, of course, prove very advantageous in a number of cases. Take the case of a man living in a house that is the property of the mental hospital committee. The payment of a lump sum of money will enable him, on retirement, to purchase a house for himself and his family. The superannuation payment, I understand, is to be calculated on a 20/80th basis where the person concerned has 20 years' service, but in some cases that will work out less favourably for the person concerned than the superannuation provision in the 1909 Act. There is also provision for individuals who desire to opt out. These really are Committee points. I am raising them to suggest to the Parliamentary Secretary that no individual should be penalised or have his position worsened by the operations of this measure.

The Bill also makes provision for the holding of local inquiries. That, of course, is very essential in connection with the work done in these institutions. I have in mind an inquiry that was held last year, I think, in Kilkenny. Speaking generally with regard to these inquiries, I think that, first of all, the Minister should satisfy himself that a prima facie case has been made before he sanctions the holding of a local inquiry. A number of these local inquiries have been held recently—there was the one in connection with the Cork Street Hospital—and it would appear to me that no preliminary examination was made in regard to some of them. I do not know whether, in connection with the Kilkenny inquiry, the Minister satisfied himself that a prima facie case was made for the holding of it. The result, at any rate, showed that the whole thing was a trumped up business, a fictitious charge.

Speaker.P: Was it not a good thing to establish that, if that were true?

It may be. At any rate, as far as the resident medical superintendent is concerned I do not know anything about him. I never had any conversation with him, good, bad or indifferent. I take it that he was legally represented at the inquiry and had to incur some cost in defending himself. My view is that it is unfair to individuals and to the ratepayers. It may be a very fine thing to establish that the institution is clear of any charges that are made, and that the running of it is above board. But the ratepayer has to foot the bill.
He is the man who demands the inquiry, and he is the man who has to be satisfied.
A group of local ratepayers.
There is only one way of satisfying the ratepayers if they think there is something wrong, and that is to hold an inquiry.
Is the Parliamentary Secretary suggesting that, irrespective of whether there are grounds for complaint or not, an inquiry should be held?
No. There are always grounds.

I am not saying that local inquiries should not be held. What I am saying is that the Minister should satisfy himself by a preliminary examination that there are grounds for the holding of an inquiry.
I can assure the Deputy that the Minister does go into these matters most carefully before he decides on the holding of an inquiry.
I am glad to have that assurance although it appeared to me that in some recent cases there were not sufficient grounds for the holding of an inquiry.
If the Deputy saw the evidence I think he would be satisfied.
Possibly I would. I am glad, as I say, to have the assurance that there is a full preliminary examination to satisfy the Minister that a prima facie case has to be made for the holding of an inquiry.
Very definitely so.

That satisfies me. Except on a few minor points, I have no complaint to make about this Bill. I think it is a step in the right direction. I am glad that additional facilities are being afforded for the treatment of certain types of cases, and for the segregation and boarding out of mental hospital patients. All these ideas are praiseworthy and the Parliamentary Secretary is to be congratulated. The only big ground for complaint that I have is that the question of the capitation grant for mental hospitals has been not merely completely ignored in the Bill, but that the Parliamentary Secretary himself nicely side-stepped it in his speech.

It is only on that issue that we clash with the Parliamentary Secretary. It is unfortunate that the increased charges which are bound to accrue under this piece of legislation will be thrown back on the local taxpayer and on one industry—the agricultural industry. The House must agree that this is becoming more and more a State service and that the mental hospital committees have become more ornamental than useful. They have no power. Substantial State provision should be made for financing the curative treatment of mental patients. That is where the Bill falls short. We deprecate that and I hope the Parliamentary Secretary will give further consideration to it even before we reach the Committee Stage.

I agree with Deputy Roddy that this is not a type of Bill which the average Deputy can discuss very thoroughly. It is a Bill which could more effectively be dealt with by members of the medical profession. The main contribution which the average Deputy can make to a debate of this kind is to ask questions. A question which occurs to me at the outset is: Why is it that the incidence of mental disease decreases in times of war and tends to increase in normal times? It would seem that the effect of the world going mad is to make many people sane. I mention that merely to indicate the complex nature of the matters with which we are called upon to deal in this Bill. It is a welcome measure inasmuch as it consolidates all cognate legislation so that local authorities, the medical profession and the legal profession will have many of their difficulties of reference removed. It is fortunate that the name “lunatic asylum” and the word “lunacy” have been practically eliminated. It strikes me, however, that it might be desirable to go a little further in regard to minor types of mental disease. I think that patients suffering from minor types of mental disease should be classified as nervous patients. That might lead to the facilities provided by this Bill being more extensively availed of. I understand that it is intended to provide auxiliary institutions and I suggest that, where such are being provided for the accommodation of patients suffering from minor mental disease, they should be described as “homes for nervous patients”. Where treatment is being provided, it should also be on the basis of nervous trouble rather than mental trouble.

MainHeading.P: I was impressed by a point made by Deputy Hughes in another debate in connection with tubercular disease. He suggested that there should be an institution for chest ailments so that people could receive treatment who might be deterred from entering an institution described as for the treatment of tuberculosis. I am not impressed by the provision in the Bill for the boarding-out of patients from mental institutions. It would not be easy to find many people who would be prepared to undertake the care of a person who had been a patient in a mental institution. I should imagine that some type of home, other than the ordinary mental institution, could be provided for that type of patient, where he would be under the care of a qualified person. That might be better than sending those patients into the ordinary, domestic home. It would have most of the advantages of an ordinary household and it would, at the same time, preserve many of the advantages of institutional treatment. No matter how we may change the names of mental institutions, they will be forbidding places. I do not think we can do much to remedy that, but we should do all that is possible. Deputy Hughes referred to the safeguarding against litigation of doctors responsible for the committal of patients. It is, perhaps, even more necessary to safeguard the patients. Nothing could be more deplorable than that a person should be wrongfully committed to a mental hospital, no matter what type of mental hospital it might be. As regards the compulsory acquisition of land for mental hospitals, I would not be prepared to go so far as Deputy Roddy went when he suggested that mental hospital authorities should have no compulsory powers. I think that, in certain cases, it might be necessary to have compulsory powers, provided that ample safeguards are accepted in the Bill to ensure that a person from whom land is compulsorily acquired is not only adequately compensated but is also given an alternative holding. It is true that there is hardly any form of activity which is better suited to mental patients than work on the land, whether it be in ordinary farm work or in horticulture in some form or another. They have, in work on the land, the advantage of outdoor exercise and fresh air, and it is also an occupation that is free from noise or other distractions which would occur in, say, a workshop, factory or anything of that kind. I believe that a very large percentage of patients in mental hospitals take very well to agricultural work and that it is found to be a satisfactory treatment for their condition.

The chief contention in regard to this Bill, of course, is the method by which it is proposed to finance it, and that is, to continue the present unsatisfactory method of financing mental institutions and mental treatment, generally. I think that the mere passing of this Bill, and the reasons which have given rise to its introduction, strengthen the case for making mental institutions a national charge. We have proposals in this Bill for the segregation of patients. Now, that might entail a certain amount of coordination between a number of counties. For instance, you might have an institution for one type of patient in one county, and an institution for the treatment of another type of patient in another county. That might be found to be desirable, and I think it would be better, simpler, and fairer to everybody concerned, if the whole scheme were financed centrally. There is also a case for centralised financing of all these mental institutions in the fact that it is desirable to afford to the mentally afflicted the most modern and up-to-date system of treatment. Accordingly, whatever new ideas are conceived or discoveries made in regard to treatment of the mentally afflicted, it is necessary that they should be passed on to every mental institution throughout the country. From that point of view, mental institutions are not really local institutions at all. Not even the most enthusiastic advocate of decentralisation and of local control would suggest that each county should be absolutely free to decide what type of institution they should have for the mentally afflicted, and what type of treatment they should give. I think that the mentally afflicted are entitled to the best treatment that can be discovered as a result of centrally-controlled and centrally-directed research. I hold, therefore, that when a service is not local—when it is a national service—it should be nationally financed.

Of course, another strong argument in regard to the financing of this Bill out of Central Funds arises out of the fact that the system of financing local administration, generally, is antiquated. As Deputy Hughes pointed out, you have numbers of people who escape from making practically any contribution to local finances, and those people will escape from making a contribution towards the finances of this Bill. Now, that is neither just, fair nor reasonable, and in order to have the burden equally distributed it is desirable that the whole cost of the administration of this service should be from Central Funds.

In conclusion, there is one feature of this Bill to which I should like to refer, and that is the provision of treatment for voluntary patients. There was a tragic case some years ago, I believe, where a person applied for admission into a mental institution and was refused on the ground that the resident medical superintendent had not power to admit him, and I think that the person concerned committed suicide afterwards. I, therefore, think that where a person applies for such treatment it is desirable that there should be no obstacle in the way of having such treatment afforded, and that is a very progressive step so far as this Bill is concerned. Finally, I should like to say that I compliment the Parliamentary Secretary; both on the Bill itself and on the full and complete statement he made in introducing it.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. M.E. Dockrell Mr. M.E. Dockrell
Speaker.P: I am very glad to see that a Mental Bill has been brought in here. It has been very much overdue. We have lagged far behind some of the most progressive countries in this matter, and I think it is high time that the legal position of persons of unsound mind was changed. Now, we have at least two new principles in connection with this Bill. The first is the principle of voluntary patients, which other Deputies have spoken about, and which I think is an excellent one. We all know that many mental diseases start as, perhaps, nervous disorders and that, if they can be treated early enough, they will lend themselves readily to treatment which, later on, they might not do. It also, I think, takes a lot of the horror and shame out of mental diseases, and that is, as the Parliamentary Secretary has recognised in this Bill, one of the most important matters in connection with curing these unfortunate people. Another new principle is that of boarding out, and I think that, with proper supervision, that system may work very well indeed, and I am sure that the Minister and the Parliamentary Secretary will see that the very greatest facilities are given for the supervision of people who are boarded out in that way. That is the kernel of the whole question of the boarding out of people of unsound mind: that they shall be properly looked after, because, if they are properly looked after, they stand a better chance of recovery outside than they would stand if they were confined in a mental institution.

Some speakers have referred to the forbidding aspect of certain mental hospitals, and I should like to join my voice to theirs. I know that there is nothing more horrible than the outside aspect of some of these institutions in this country. I quite admit that that is not the Minister's fault or the fault of the Department which deals with these matters, but the fact remains that most of them are terrible looking institutions from the outside, and I have often thought that many of the people who went in there would stand a very poor chance of recovery if they were at all sensible to the appearance of these institutions. However, I think this Bill will, perhaps, do a great deal to remedy that situation. Under the arrangements proposed to be carried out as a result of this Bill, it will be possible to erect new buildings, what I might refer to as curative buildings rather than mental hospitals, and I am sure these will be designed in a way which will benefit the patients very greatly.

A Deputy speaking here to-day asked that doctors should be adequately protected in regard to the question of certifying patients. Now I have great sympathy with doctors, and I think most doctors dislike nothing more than being asked to certify any person, but I think the best protection we can give any doctor is the obvious insanity of a patient. If we go beyond that we get ourselves into the position in which we are protecting the doctor to the possible detriment of the patient and that would be a situation which, I am sure, the members of the medical profession themselves would be the last to desire.

MainHeading.P: There is another provision in this Bill which is quite new, namely, that relating to the liability of certain persons to maintain the insane. In Part XVII I see that every legitimate person shall be liable to maintain his or her father or mother. I should not like to say or do anything which would cut across filial duty but I think, at the same time, that we are introducing an entirely new principle in making it mandatory on children to maintain their parents in such circumstances. I can see that certain circumstances may arise in which, by reason of having to make a contribution to a mental hospital, an unfortunate young man or woman, may have his or her whole life seriously affected. A man's prospects of getting married or living in a decent state may be seriously impaired by reason of the contribution that he may be called upon to make to maintain his father or mother who is of unsound mind. I think I am correct in saying that the payment which he will have to make will ultimately be decided by the District Court.

Speaker.P: In the case of a chargeable patient, it would be decided by the public assistance authority.
The remedy of the person who is a relative lies in an application to the District Court. Is that not the ultimate decider of his ability to pay?
Yes.

That, I think, is placing a very great burden on the District Justice. He is being asked to decide what amount a person coming before him can pay for a relative who is of unsound mind. Yet when a person is in need of home assistance, we have committees and trained officers to decide how much money he can get, but when it is a question of what a person who has to maintain a man or woman of unsound mind can pay, the sole decision rests with the District Justice. I am afraid that under that provision we shall place a very harsh burden on certain relatives of such people. I know the provision is capable of many interpretations but I should welcome more discussion on it.

MainHeading.P: It is further provided that every illegitimate person shall be liable to maintain his or her mother. The same argument applies there, perhaps to a somewhat greater extent. A man is liable to maintain such of his legitimate children as for the time being are under the age of 16 years of age. He would be liable to maintain his children if they are of unsound mind only for 14 years at the most because I do not suppose that weakmindedness would become apparent in a child before the child was two years old and probably not until it was four or five years old. The man, therefore, would not have to maintain his children for more than 14 years at the outside, and probably for not more than ten or twelve. Yet a child has to maintain his parents all their lives. Why does not a father have to maintain his children until they die just as the children have to maintain their parents until death?

Speaker.P: Children have only one father but the father may have many children.

They might not be all of unsound mind. Mind you, there may be cases in which lunacy in parents may be brought about and, in many cases is brought about, directly through the actions of the parents themselves. You may have circumstances in which the parent has been, perhaps, a drunkard or has led a bad life in other ways and as a result of that life becomes of unsound mind. The unfortunate child after having had a very poor parent for a long time has afterwards to maintain that parent in an institution as a person of unsound mind.

MainHeading.P: Another feature of the Bill is that a woman is liable to maintain her illegitimate children while a man does not have to maintain his illegitimate children. Would the Parliamentary Secretary enlighten the House as to why, in cases where it has been legally proved that a man is the father of illegitimate children, he does not have to maintain them? Supposing there is an affiliation order against him, in other words that he is the legally recognised father, why has he not to maintain these children? I think that is a great defect in the Bill. The mother has to maintain her illegitimate children but the father gets off scot-free. Again, it is provided that every married woman shall be liable to maintain her husband. I think that is a radical departure from the existing law. I am not a lawyer but I do not know that a married woman is liable in all circumstances for the debts of her husband under the existing law. Yet, she is liable under this Bill to maintain him if he becomes a lunatic. I think that provision will hit certain women very harshly because in general women do not earn as large salaries as men do. They earn, perhaps, about £2 10s. a week. If you take anything from such a woman, even a few shillings a week, you are pushing herwage below the level on which she can live. I would welcome more explanation of the liability of various persons to maintain their relatives who are of unsound mind. I would also welcome more discussion of this matter, perhaps outside the House, because I do not think the public generally have realised the radical departure that this Bill is from existing law, even quite outside the law in relation to persons of unsound mind. There remain the financial aspects of the Bill. I think it is a pity that it should altogether have been put on to the local authorities. They are already very much overburdened.

In conclusion, I should like to say that I welcome this Bill. I think everybody in the House will welcome it, and I hope it will be only the commencement of a change in the attitude of the whole country towards lunacy. Not of course in the minds of medical people, but in the mind of the ordinary citizen, lunacy has been something shameful and horrible. Yet, the mind is just as capable of being cured as any other part of the body which is attacked by disease. This is our legal recognition of that fact. I hope this Bill is the charter for the mentally unsound.
